thread.title: Bickell Foundation returns to Waukegan to help more pit bills Lake County News-Sun
thread.title_full: Bickell Foundation returns to Waukegan to help more pit bills - Lake County News-Sun

author: Denys Bucksten
title: Bickell Foundation returns to Waukegan to help more pit bills Lake County News-Sun
text:
About 125 pit bulls were treated Sunday to a free health clinic sponsored by the Bryan & Amanda Bickell Foundation at Waukegan Animal Control.
Depending on their needs, dogs, including many puppies, were given physical exams, vaccinated, micro-chipped and given appointments for free spay or neutering with area veterinarians.
The clinic was a continuation of a late July effort, the Bickell Foundation's first, in which over 200 dogs were treated to services, but over 150 more people and their pets were turned away on a sweltering, humid day.
Several veterinarians and staff members returned on Sunday, volunteering their services at the morning clinic on McAree Road.
Amanda Bickell, wife of Chicago Blackhawks forward Bryan Bickell, met with dozens of the pit bull owners as Waukegan has been on the foundation's radar for a long time.
Man charged in pit bull attack on 2 Indiana women Tribune wire reports An Indiana man is facing misdemeanor charges after his pit bulls mauled and seriously injured two young women.
Fifty-year-old Richard L. Darter of the Carroll County town of Cutler was charged Friday with eight counts of dog bite liability resulting in serious bodily injury.
The women were walking...
An Indiana man is facing misdemeanor charges after his pit bulls mauled and seriously injured two young women.
Fifty-year-old Richard L. Darter of the Carroll County town of Cutler was charged Friday with eight counts of dog bite liability resulting in serious bodily injury.
The women were walking...
(Tribune wire reports) "Last time we visited Waukegan we saw the need and knew there were tons of people who were interested in helping their dogs and helping themselves out and we knew we had to come back," she said.
Asked if people who get pit bulls should have planned for the financing of their own health care, Bickell said, "There's part of me that says yes, you need to be able to (afford) to take care of your dog, but at the same time, these people are taking care of their dogs. They're coming here and making sure their dogs get spayed and neutered, getting all their shots. They are loving and caring animal owners and that's all we can ask for."
Sunday's clinic was better organized than the first, said Alicia Boemi, executive director of the Bickell Foundation.
Large pit bull population in Waukegan prompts second vaccination clinic Denys Bucksten A second, highly anticipated pit bull health clinic will be Sunday, Oct. 11, from 9 a.m. until noon at Waukegan Animal Control, 1698 N. McAree Road.
The free clinic, sponsored by the Bryan & Amanda Bickell Foundation, is for pit bull owners living in Waukegan. Owners with proper identification can...
A second, highly anticipated pit bull health clinic will be Sunday, Oct. 11, from 9 a.m. until noon at Waukegan Animal Control, 1698 N. McAree Road.
The free clinic, sponsored by the Bryan & Amanda Bickell Foundation, is for pit bull owners living in Waukegan. Owners with proper identification can...
(Denys Bucksten) Instead of one long line feeding into the outdoor clinic adjacent to animal control, separate stations were set up for shots, micro-chipping and appointment takers for spay/neuter.
The first station at the clinic was a small tent and table with free high-end collars and harnesses for all dogs.
The Bickell Foundation worked with Waukegan Animal Control Director Susan Elliott and volunteers from area rescue organizations.
Denys Bucksten is a freelancer for the News-Sun.
